text:
Carl Schurz Park: A set of 3 views of the Gracie Mansion, located in the northern end of the Park at what would be the foot of East 88th Street, if the street continued to the East River. This set shows the front of the house, that overlooked the East River. 1913.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

The house was made the official residence of the Mayor of the City of New York on January 8, 1942 by an act of the Board of Estimate.

See "The New York Times," January 9, 1942.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.

title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.

text:
(1) Carl Schurz Park: A view westward on the Promenade, showing the Park on the left and the East River on the right. Beyond East End Ave., East 89th Street begins; upon the north side of which are the buildings of the House of the Good Shepherd. Note the U.S. Volunteer Life Saving Station on the rivers edge.

P. L. Sperr.

August 2, 1927.

(2) The same, from the northwestern corner of the Park.

May 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Promenade; House of The Good Shepherd; United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps.

title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Promenade; House of The Good Shepherd; United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps.

text:
(1)
Carl Schurz Park: A view of the East River frontage of the northern part of the park, with Gracie Mansion there in. Shown in the background are houses on the west side of East End Ave., and the spire atop a building of the House of the Good Shepherd; all at East 89th Street.

August 31, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the south and east (front) sides of the Gracie Mansion as viewed northward from a point in the Park. The East River embankment is on the right.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies, Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(3)
A view similar to No. 2. Note the foot path, benches, and general improvements; a W.P.A. project.
March 29, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

On January 8, 1962, the Board of Estimate designated the Gracie Mansion to the official residence of the Mayor of the City of New York.
See "The New York Times," January 9, 1962, p. 15.
title: Manhattan: Carl Schurz Park - Gracie Mansion.

text:
89th Street, north side, from East End to York Avenues. All of the buildings seen on this block belong to the House of The Good Shepherd which is a Roman Catholic home for women.
August 2, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Photostat negative(matte) no. 15

East 89th Street, north side, between East End (Ave. B) and York (Ave. A) Aves. Site formerly occupied by the House of Good Shepherd.

March 29, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

East End Avenue at N. W. corner of 89th Street, showing former site of the House of the Good Shepherd.
March 29, 1929.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

East River, New York's shoreline, north from East 79th to East 89th Streets, showing (left to right) No. 1 East End Ave. (14-story apartment house); the Yorkgate; the Yorkville Ice Sales Corp.; the Brearly School; the 16-story apartment house No. 10-12 Gracie Square (East 84th Street); and a portion of Carl Schurz Park.
Autumn 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, a more limited view. These views are seen from Welfare Island.
April 5, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Shore and skyline of Manhattan between East 78th and 89th Streets - Queensborough Bridge - [Brearly School; Yorkgate; Yorkville Ice Sales Corporation.]

text:
East 89th Street, north side, at the northern terminus of East End Ave. This area, north of Carl Schurz Park is being filled in. The frame building shown on piles, is a U.S. Vol. Life Saving Station, and is located at the foot of East 90th Street.

March 29, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, another angle.

March 29, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

A view slightly westward.

March 29, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
